question: In contrast to gambling, derivatives speculation:
B: is a form of financial risk taking.
C: benefits the financial markets and thus society.

question: To the holder of a long position, it is more desirable to own a forward contract than a futures contract when interest rates and futures prices are:
B: uncorrelated.
C: positively correlated.

question: The buyer of an option has a contingent claim in the sense that the option creates:
B: an obligation.
C: a linear payoff with respect to gains and losses of the underlying.

question: A futures contract is best described as a contract that is:
B: subject to credit risk.
C: marked to market throughout the trading day.

question: At expiration, a European put option will be valuable if the exercise price is:
B: equal to the underlying price.
C: greater than the underlying price.

question: To determine the price of an option today, the binomial model requires:
A: selling one put and buying one offsetting call.
B: buying one unit of the underlying and selling one matching call.
C: using the risk-free rate to determine the required number of units of the underlying.

question: Which of the following statements regarding commodity derivatives is correct?
A: The primary commodity derivatives are futures.
B: Commodities are subject to a set of well-defined risk factors.
C: Commodity traders and financial traders today are distinct groups within the financial world.

question: In contrast to a forward contract, a futures contract:
B: is initiated at a zero value.
C: is marked-to-market daily.

question: At expiration, American call options are worth:
B: the same as European call options.
C: more than European call options.

question: Compared with exchange-traded derivatives, over-the-counter derivatives would most likely be described as:
B: less transparent.
C: more transparent.

question: Holding an asset and buying a put on that asset is equivalent to:
B: buying a risk-free zero-coupon bond and selling a call option.
C: selling a risk-free zero-coupon bond and buying a call option.

question: Under put–call–forward parity, which of the followingtransactions is risk free:
A: Short call, long put, long forward contract, long\nrisk-free bond.
B: Long call, short put, long forward contract, short\nrisk-free bond.
C: Long call, long put, short forward contract, short\nrisk-free bond.

question: Combining a protective put with a forward contractgenerates equivalent outcomes at expiration to those of a:
B: long call combined with a short asset.
C: forward contract combined with a risk-free bond.

question: If a call option is priced higher than the binomial model predicts, investors can earn a return in excess of the risk-free rate by:
A: investing at the risk-free rate, selling a call, and selling the underlying.
B: borrowing at the risk-free rate, buying a call, and buying the underlying.
C: borrowing at the risk-free rate, selling a call, and buying the underlying.

question: A beneficial opportunity created by the derivatives market is the ability to:
A: adjust risk exposures to desired levels.
B: generate returns proportional to movements in the underlying.
C: simultaneously take long positions in multiple highly liquid fixed-income securities.

question: A characteristic of forward commitments is that they:
B: do not depend on the outcome or payoff of an underlying asset.
C: provide one party the right to engage in future transactions on terms agreed on in advance.

question: Which of the following combinations replicates a long derivative position?
A: A short derivative and a long asset
B: A long asset and a short risk-free bond
C: A short derivative and a short risk-free bond

question: Compared with the underlying spot market, derivative markets are more likely to have:
B: higher transaction costs.
C: higher capital requirements.

question: Which of the following derivatives provide payoffs that are non-linearly related to the payoffs of the underlying?
B: Forwards
C: Interest-rate swaps

question: A European call option and a European put option are written on the same underlying, and both options have the same expiration date and exercise price. At expiration, it is possible that both options will have:
B: the same value.
C: positive values.

question: In a declining interest rate environment, compared with a sequential-pay CMO's Class A tranche, its Class C tranche will be repaid：
B: at the same pace.
C: later.

question: Based on the binomial model, an increase in the actual probability of an upward move in the underlying will result in the option price:
B: remaining the same.
C: increasing.

question: If no cash is initially exchanged, a swap is comparable to a series of forward contracts when:
B: the combined value of all the forward contracts is zero.
C: all the forward contracts have the same agreed-on price.

question: With respect to a forward contract, as market conditions change:
B: only the value fluctuates.
C: both the price and the value fluctuate.

question: The junior and senior tranches of an asset-backed security:
B: have claims on separate underlying portfolios.
C: may be differentially impacted by prepayments or credit losses.

question: Forward commitments subject to default are:
B: futures and interest rate swaps.
C: interest rate swaps and forwards.

question: The value of a European call option at expiration is the greater of zero or the:
B: value of the underlying minus the exercise price.
C: exercise price minus the value of the underlying.

question: Which of the following transactions is the equivalent of a synthetic long call position?
A: Long asset, long put, short call
B: Long asset, long put, short bond
C: Short asset, long call, long bond

question: It is more desirable to own a forward contract than a futures contract to the holder of a long position when interest rates and futures prices are:
B: Positively correlated.
C: Negatively correlated.

question: Which of the following statements best portrays the full implementation of post-financial-crisis regulations in the OTC derivatives market?
B: Most transactions need to be reported to regulators.
C: All transactions must be cleared through central clearing agencies.

question: In contrast to contingent claims, forward contracts:
A: have their prices chosen by the participants.
B: could end in default by either party.
C: can be exercised by physical or cash delivery.

question: At the initiation of a forward contract on an asset that neither receives benefits nor incurs carrying costs during the term of the contract, the forward price is equal to the:
B: future value of the spot price.
C: present value of the spot price.

question: Which of the following is most likely the underlying of a plain vanilla interest rate swap?
B: 10-year US Treasury bond
C: Bloomberg Barclay’s US Aggregate Bond Index

question: The derivative markets tend to:
A: transfer liquidity from the broader financial markets.
B: not reflect fundamental value after it is restored in the underlying market.
C: offer a less costly way to exploit mispricing in comparison to other free and competitive financial markets.

question: Assume an asset pays no dividends or interest, and also assume that the asset does not yield any non-financial benefits or incur any carrying cost. At initiation, the price of a forward contract on that asset is:
A: lower than the value of the contract.
B: equal to the value of the contract.
C: greater than the value of the contract.

question: An arbitrage transaction generates a net inflow of funds:
B: at the end of the holding period.
C: at the start of the holding period.

question: Derivatives may contribute to financial contagion because of the:
A: centrally cleared nature of OTC derivatives.
B: associated significant costs and high capital requirements.
C: reliance by derivatives speculators on large amounts of leverage.

question: Which of the following is most likely to be a destabilizing consequence of speculation using derivatives?
A: Increased defaults by speculators and creditors
B: Market price swings resulting from arbitrage activities
C: The creation of trading strategies that result in asymmetric performance

question: If the present value of storage costs exceeds the present value of its convenience yield, then the commodity’s forward price is most likely:
A: less than the spot price compounded at the risk-free rate.
B: the same as the spot price compounded at the risk-free rate.
C: higher than the spot price compounded at the risk-free rate.

question: For a European call option with two months until expiration, if the spot price is below the exercise price, the call option will most likely have:
B: positive time value.
C: positive exercise value.

question: The value of a swap is equal to the present value of the:
B: net cash flow payments from the swap.
C: underlying at the end of the contract.

question: In contrast to contingent claims, forward commitments provide the:
A: right to buy or sell the underlying asset in the future.
B: obligation to buy or sell the underlying asset in the future.
C: promise to provide credit protection in the event of default.

question: An interest rate swap is a derivative contract in which:
A: two parties agree to exchange a series of cash flows.
B: the credit seller provides protection to the credit buyer.
C: the buyer has the right to purchase the underlying from the seller.

question: The value of a European put option can be either directly or inversely related to the:
B: time to expiration.
C: volatility of the underlying.

question: If the net cost of carry of an asset is positive, then the price of a forward contract on that asset is most likely:
A: lower than if the net cost of carry was zero.
B: the same as if the net cost of carry was zero.
C: higher than if the net cost of carry was zero.

question: The value of a forward contract at expiration is:
A: positive to the long party if the spot price is higher than the forward price.
B: negative to the short party if the forward price is higher than the spot price.
C: positive to the short party if the spot price is higher than the forward price.

question: For a given CDO, which of the following tranches is most likely to have the highest expected return?
B: Senior
C: Mezzanine

question: Which of the following circumstances will most likely affect the value of an American call option relative to a European call option?
B: Expiration date occurs
C: The risk-free rate changes

question: The price of a swap typically:
B: fluctuates over the life of the contract.
C: is obtained through a process of replication.

question: A European put option on a dividend-paying stock is most likely to increase if there is an increase in:
B: the risk-free rate.
C: dividend payments.

question: A plain vanilla interest rate swap is also known as:
B: a fixed-for-floating swap.
C: an overnight indexed swap.

question: Which of the following derivatives is classified as a contingent claim?
B: Interest rate swaps
C: Credit default swaps

question: Which of the following factors is shared by forwards and futures contracts?
B: Flexible settlement arrangements
C: Nearly equivalent profits by expiration

question: Assume a call option’s strike price is initially equal to the price of its underlying asset. Based on the binomial model, if the volatility of the underlying decreases, the lower of the two potential payoff values of the hedge portfolio:
B: remains the same.
C: increases.

question: Most derivatives are priced by:
A: assuming that the market offers arbitrage opportunities.
B: discounting the expected payoff of the derivative at the risk-free rate.
C: applying a risk premium to the expected payoff of the derivative and its risk.

question: The notional principal of a swap is:
A: not exchanged in the case of an interest rate swap.
B: a fixed amount whenever it is matched with a loan.
C: equal to the amount owed by one swap party to the other.

question: Which of the following characteristics is least likely to be a benefit associated with using derivatives?
B: Payoffs similar to those associated with the underlying
C: Greater opportunities to go short compared with the spot market

question: Which of the following derivatives is least likely to have a value of zero at initiation of the contract?
B: Options
C: Forwards

question: Which of the following derivatives allows an investor to pay the return on a stock index and receive a fixed rate?
B: Stock warrant
C: Index futures contract

question: Currency swaps are:
B: commonly used to manage interest rate risk.

question: The value of a swap typically:
B: is obtained through replication.
C: does not fluctuate over the life of the contract.

question: Which of the following statements most likely contributes to the view that derivatives have some role in causing financial crashes?
A: Derivatives are the primary means by which leverage and related excessive risk is brought into financial markets.
B: Growth in the number of investors willing to speculate in derivatives markets leads to excessive speculative trading.
C: Restrictions on derivatives, such as enhanced collateral requirements and credit mitigation measures, in the years leading up to crashes introduce market rigidity.

question: Which of the following factors most likely explains why the spot price of a commodity in short supply can be greater than its forward price?
B: Lack of dividends
C: Convenience yield

question: A swap is:
A: more like a forward than a futures contract.
B: subject to simultaneous default by both parties.
C: based on an exchange of two series of fixed cash flows.

question: Which of the following statements explains a characteristic of futures price limits? Price limits:
A: help the clearinghouse manage its credit exposure.
B: can typically be expanded intra-day by willing traders.

question: Which of the following options grants the holder the right to purchase the underlying prior to expiration?
B: European-style call option
C: American-style call option

question: An at-the-money American call option on a stock that pays no dividends has three months remaining until expiration. The market value of the option will most likely be:
B: equal to its exercise value.

question: The complex nature of derivatives has led to:
A: reliable financial models of derivatives markets.
B: widespread trust in applying scientific principles to derivatives.
C: financial industry employment of mathematicians and physicists.

A: designate the value of the underlying at contract initiation.

B: The initial margin required is typically at least 10% of the futures price.

question: Which of the following is least likely to be required by the binomial option pricing model?
B: Two possible prices one period later
C: Actual probabilities of the up and down moves

question: The clearing and settlement process of an exchange-traded derivatives market:
B: provides transparency and flexibility.
C: takes longer than that of most securities exchanges.

question: The price of a forward contract:
A: is the amount paid at initiation.
B: is the amount paid at expiration.
C: fluctuates over the term of the contract.

question: If the risk-free rate increases, the value of an in-the-money European put option will most likely:
B: remain the same.
C: increase.

question: Exchange-traded derivatives are:
B: traded through an informal network.

B: seller provides protection to the buyer against the credit risk of a third party.

B: equal to forward prices.

A: exercise price minus the value of the underlying.
